title: Thames & Kosmos Motors & Generators Science Kit | 25 Guided STEM Experiment Lessons | 48 Page Color Student Guide | Grades 3-6 | Ages 8+ | Play & Learn | Parents' Choice Silver Award Winner
descriptions:
Thames & Kosmos Motors & Generators Science Kit

Inspire hands-on STEM learning with a kit that lets kids see electricity and magnetism in action. With an electric motor housed in transparent plastic, students can watch components move as they convert electricity into motion—and then reconfigure the setup into a hand-crank generator to convert motion back into electricity.

Key features:
- 25 guided experiments covering magnetism, circuits, gears, and drive trains.
- Two-in-one build: battery-powered electric motor and hand-crank electric generator.
- Transparent motor housing for clear visualization of how motors work.
- Explore magnetic fields, electric current, and energy conversion (electrical-to-kinetic and kinetic-to-electrical).
- STEM education focus with real-world engineering concepts.
- Award-winning: Parents’ Choice Silver Award.

What’s included:
- Electric motor/generator components (transparent housing).
- 60-page full-color manual (2012 edition) with step-by-step instructions.
- 48-page full-color student guide for classroom or at-home use.

Learning outcomes:
- Understand how electric motors and generators function.
- Build simple circuits and investigate magnetic fields.
- Learn about gears and drive-trains and how they transmit motion and force.
- Grasp core energy conversion principles.

Specifications:
- Grade level: 3–6
- Ages: 8+
- Category: Electronic learning / STEM
- Dimensions: 13.1 in (H) x 8.9 in (W) x 2.6 in (D)
- Weight: 1.3 lb
- Year: 2012

Why it’s great:
- Visual, tactile learning: the see-through motor demystifies complex concepts.
- Flexible use: ideal for classrooms, homeschool, or curious young makers.
- Clear, supportive guides make setup and experimentation straightforward for beginners.

Give young scientists the power to build, test, and truly understand how motors and generators work—one engaging experiment at a time.
